properties.statement:
On the side of a building, this mural, sponsored by LocalColor SJ, consists of 100 individual 3’x3’ mural tiles designed and painted by local artists. The resulting 65 ft long wall comes together as a visual tapestry of images, symbols and meanings that showcases San Jose’s artistic diversity and stands as an example of the non-profit’s goals of creating collaborative opportunities for local makers. 

In “The 100 Block Mural” the representation of the individual and collective come together in an interdependent representation of society. Though each tile represents an individual identity, aspiration, or life, they do not exist as wholly separate works, but rather a holistic representation of the city. Metropolitan centers are portrayed as homogenous, fast paced, loud and unfamiliar spaces. “The 100 Block Mural” pushes back on the perspective to show the breadth of life, worldviews, and experiences of individuals who live, work, and recreate throughout the city. The viewer is presented with 100 stories that contribute to the epic that is San Jose.

I am from faces I do not recognize 
And tongues I cannot speak
From the writings of Sui Sin Far, 
Of both the far and middle East
I am from ballads of kingdoms, oriental dreams
And histories lost, that tie together all things

I am from the California gold mines deep within the earth, 
Where rough-hewn hands work in rhythm
With the clashes of metal and whistling steam
My pó po, wading in rice paddies, hearing war planes fly overhead
The smell of orchid and jasmine, or pungent tang of dry herbs,
Wafting through old dormitories on Angel Island

I am from the pogroms of Eastern Europe (Poland, Ukraine, I can’t be sure)
That left our blood and names muddled, wrapped with
Patterned cloth for safekeeping in the journey ahead
Hushed coven meetings of swarthy women, with
Their yiddish etched, sizzling, in the kitchen air
Woven with familiar taste of pickled goods and warm bread

I am from Michigan’s cast-iron sky, whose harsh
Snow is as soft as Ezekiel Solomon’s furs
Where a sculpture of my grandmother sings out to me 
In her bronze song, high and lonely across the years
Faint, like the perfume that lingers on her scarves
Musky and sweet as it clings to the skin

I am from the heat of the last apricot orchard in bloom
The bitterness of hard, unripened fruit
From the smell of lanolin and dog’s fur, wet from the rain
That pitter-patters the mossy roof while I sleep 
Soothed by the mourning dove’s call
I am here, I am here

I am from words I can’t pronounce
And names with several iterations
Conjured by unseen mitzvahs 
and old-world superstition
I am from the end
But also the beginning
properties.bio url: Tessa (b. 1993) was raised, and currently resides, in the California Bay Area where she received her Bachelors of Fine Arts and Associates in Art History. As an alum of SJSU she continues to pursue her passion for illustration, printmaking, and writing. Her work focuses on exploring her deep love of the natural world as well as the complexities of self-identity within queer and bi-racial communities.

properties.statement:
110 Rio Robles, San Jose is the site which occupied most of my hours when I became officially diagnosed with “migraines with photophobia.” At the time I was very perplexed. I didn’t know how aches in my eyeballs counted as migraines. After leaving the company I went on a three-month break from computers, thinking that would fix my issue (I only got headaches when looking at computer screens) but when I slowly returned to the virtual world, I found my light-tolerance grinding down. Later I set up a lunch date (also in San Jose)  with the same co-worker who read my palm; he asked me, “You’re better now, right?” only to be surprised with the unfortunate truth. But this was only the beginning of a long and arduous saga of learning to live with a disability—one that even my doctors struggled to assist me with (my last two neurologists ejected me from their practices, citing that my condition was atypical and they couldn’t help me anymore). 

Because of my disability, San Jose has been my home for the last several years. I had plans of graduate school, even flying out to scope out programs, but those drowned under the tide of new health-related problems.  Sometimes I feel ashamed about not having “overcome” like many other people with disabilities have, but, eh, each has their own journey. At least, despite the fluctuating landscape of my health, one thing has remained steadfast—my love for writing. The truest change is how I put the words on the page. So here I am, finding power and grace amidst the light.
properties.bio url: L.D. Nguyen lives inside of comic books but frequently emerges from this 2-D universe to write short fiction and creative nonfiction, primarily about gender and sexuality. Her zodiac animal is the wood horse, which are allegedly good at self-deprecating humor. For three years she typed her material blind because of her severe light-sensitivity, and she continues to write mostly blind due to headaches from eye-movement. Her work has appeared in New Haven Review, Broken Pencil, Litro, Curve, and others. She lives in the Bay Area, California with her cat.

properties.statement:
Stretching along the Guadalupe River Trail, this monumental mural by artist Alfonso Salazar was painted as part of the third Artist-In-Residence program at San Jose Walls. The work is both a depiction of the present and past of the Muwekma Ohlone tribe and a proclamation of resistance. The group, which includes Indigenous people from across the San Francisco Bay region, was stripped of their rights in 1927, despite their continual presence in their ancestral home. This public artwork runs along Thámien Rúmmey, an ancestral site for the Muwekma Ohlone, now known as the Guadalupe River, and depicts tribal leaders, elders and the landscape and flora and fauna of the region. Central to the mural is a portrait of Muwekma Ohlone Chairwoman Charlene Nijmeh, wearing the traditional warrior eagle headpiece of the tribe. On either side of her, floating in the clouds are portraits of the elders of the tribe, while below are children engaged in traditional activities, a symbol of the continual and continuing life and traditions of the Muwekma Ohlone people. Painted in bold letters are the words “Makkin Mak Nommo (We Are Still Here).”

Salazar and the San Jose Walls team worked closely with Chairwoman Nijmeh and the Muwekma Ohlone tribe to create a work of art that not only honors the history of the tribe and marks the site of the Guadalupe River, but equally serves as a statement of resistance to narratives that Indigenous communities are historical, rather than present and alive. Moreover, this work serves to beautify and revitalize the Guadalupe River Trail, thus honoring the Muwekma Ohlone through action and utilizing art as a space for community gathering and wellness.

Inspired by the recent political turmoil in Hong Kong, Flower Respirator explores the imagery of and aesthetic fashions of protest. Respirator inspired by the protests in Hong Kong. Based on 3M respirators and their iconic pink filters. The flowers act as filters for this piece. Blend of militaristic and mechanical shapes contrasted with soft curves of flowers. Piece made primarily with polygons and subdivisions and manipulation of edges.

The imagery of the lotus flower and cherry blossoms represent the flag of the Hong Kong Special Autonomous Region. The respirator is iconic and a clear reference to the infamous rise of the 3M respirator to the global consciousness. The baseball bat and toppled barrier fences depict violence and struggle. 

The scene is set up in a way in which the respirator is almost a shrine - a symbol of struggle and freedom. Lead slugs from fired weapons impact onto an invisible forcefield, implying that this shrine and mask itself - is impervious.

This poem is a meditation upon the variety of personal approaches to hiking in the foothills above Santa Clara Valley. It also features a variety of local flora and fauna. From the elevated perspective of the Cora Older Trail, the entire South Bay Area is visible. On a clear day, the hiker may enjoy a view of the bay and its bridges, as well as the local landmarks of Stanford University, NASA Research Center & Moffett Field, Mount Diablo, the Apple campus, Levi Stadium, the San Jose skyline, and the eastern foothills.
properties.bio url: David Denny is a poet and fiction writer living in Cupertino. Recent books include Sometimes Only the Sad Songs Will Do, Some Divine Commotion, The Gill Man in Purgatory, and Fool in the Attic. He is Professor of English at De Anza College and a recipient of an Artist Laureate Award from the Silicon Valley Arts Council.
properties.text submission:
David Denny

Hikers, Three Varieties

        after Jeffrey Harrison

There are those for whom the mountain is just 
one more fitness course made to work the quads 
and boost the heart rate. Once they hit the peak, 
they claim the view, comment on the weather, 
compare pedometers. They can’t stand still 
for long lest their muscles begin to cool and cramp. 
They can’t wait to descend, to arrive at the coffee shop 
in full regalia and check today’s trail off their list. 
For them, one switch-backed, fat-burning ascent 
may very well be mistaken for another.

And there are those for whom the hike is a social 
outing—a chance to walk their dogs and complain 
of their lot: their inattentive spouse, their burdensome 
children. When they finally stumble across the bench 
in the clearing, Fido straining at the leash, tongue 
lolling, they sit just long enough to water the animal and 
ready the plastic baggie for collection. They’ve missed 
the quail and white-tailed deer, the rattlesnake and 
painted ladies flittering among trailside thistles. 
No wild thought has intruded upon their day.

And then there are those lonesome fools for whom 
the trail is a listening post on the universe. Attuned to 
the daily office of blossom and rot, their ears are pricked up 
for mystery borne upon the liquid rustle of summer leaves. 
Their eyes wander towards the shadowy undergrowth, 
the wagging branch, the tremendous wings slicing 
across the sky. They break through at the startling peak 
just as the breeze’s lullaby chimes its final notes. 
Stalked by some divine commotion, they gaze 
over the fertile valley, speechless, attentive, still.

properties.statement:
Created for SJSU by renowned Chicana artist, activist and scholar Judy Baca, the arch commemorates Mexican-American labor leader and civil rights activist Cesar Chavez through images of his life and work.

The structure is based on a Mayan corbelled arch design with Spanish and indigenous roots and features mosaic tile murals. The exterior pillars depict Dolores Huerta, co-founder of the United Farm Workers, and Mahatma Gandhi, whose philosophy of non-violence was an inspiration to Chavez are presented as two pillars for the work of the United Farm Workers Union, which is represented at the top of the arch through it’s symbol -- the eagle.

The opposite side pillars depict a male and female farm worker from the Salinas Valley, while the interior of the arch is dedicated to a portrait of Chavez, a nod from Baca to the activist’s humble nature. The Virgin of Guadalupe symbolically blesses Chavez’s actions, while a skull represents the deaths of farm workers from pesticides. 

Placed adjacent to the Student Union building and off of an important pedestrian passageway, the Arch is designed to be circumambulated and entered. For Baca, as students and visitors to SJSU move through the arch and learn of Chavez and his work, their own bodies are symbolically transformed from witnesses to activists.
properties.title of work: Arch of Dignity, Equality, and Justice

properties.statement: This postcard was designed with the concept of social distancing in mind. In these tough times, I feel the urge to return to a simpler, more nostalgic time. This is an digital illustration on top of a photo I took years ago. It's a representation of how distant, but connected I feel with my friends and family whether they are an ocean away or right next door.

properties.statement:
Created by Wayne Alaniz Healy and David Rivas Botello, founders of the Los Angeles based art collective East Los Streetscapers, and sculptor Alejandro De La Loza, this concrete and bronze sculpture features murals and bas-relief sculpture depicting the 1777 establishment of San José as the first civilian Spanish settlement in California. Painted in the group’s colorful signature style, which emerged from the Chicano Mural Movement of the 1960s-70’s, the murals depict the day to day lives of the unnamed settlers from their agricultural prowess to their adobe homes. 

The “Commemoration of the Founding of Pueblo De Guadalupe San Jose” challenges the narrative that California was born out of the Gold Rush. Serving as a reminder that the history of European settlement in the state dates back beyond 1849. The seal of the State California bears the image of Athena, who was born fully matured from the head of Zeus. The memorial is an act of resistance to the singular narrative of American settlement, acknowledging Spanish and Mexican settlement and rule that had been present since 1697.

This series of murals by eight invited artists focuses on textile arts from a diverse group of cultural traditions. Sponsored by Local Color SJ and the San Jose Museum of Quilts and Textiles at the site of the SoFA Pocket Park, a revitalized parking lot which now houses Veggielution’s urban demonstration garden, this group of murals is a site of resistance that depicts San José’s diverse communities through the lens of their textile arts.

Beginning with the challenge of depicting textiles in two-dimensional form and translating the sensory qualities of texture and material onto a brick wall surface, the artists each utilized personal style to explore their own cultural traditions. The resulting murals depict the intricate and unique aesthetics of traditional African textiles, embroidered Huipils from Mexico and Guatemala, Japanese sashiko embroidery, Navajo blankets, Hmong batik cloths, Chinese symbols, and gingham plaid from the United States. 

The site functions as a beautiful and open outdoor gallery, available and accessible to all members of the public. In this way, and through the efforts of Veggielution and the surrounding cultural institutions, it serves as a site of community dialogue, engagement, and action.

The SoFA Pocket Murals, located in the South First Area of San Jose, are a celebration of the diversity that makes up San Jose. While also standing as a symbol of resistance in the face of development. As SoFA is rejuvenated, maintaining the connection to the cultural vibrancy that has been a hallmark of the community serves as a living memory that will inspire newcomers to ask questions and seek out its cultural history.

Equally as important, these murals are a welcome home to those who are from here and returning, and those who are just arriving. They are an invitation to add to the breadth of diversity of the city and a guard against forgetting the past.

properties.statement: A short tasteful non-fiction piece about my time at San Jose's gay bisexual bathhouse.
properties.bio url: I have lived in San Jose from the time I was two.   I did all my schooling up to an MFA in Creative Writing with a focus in Poetry.  I'm just another person trying to survive the grind of Silicon Valley.
properties.text submission:
On Friday March 15, 2020, my boyfriend and I dressed down to only towels saw on the news of a virus spreading quickly with a high death rate.  A man from the dark, also dressed in nothing only but a towel, watched with us, laughed, and said it was nothing but the flu.  When I left The Watergarden that day, I knew, and my boyfriend knew, this place would be closed.
	The first time I heard about the Watergarden was in my twenties. A friend and I saw two men enter the building as we were walking to our cars from a Billy DeFrank Center writing workshop.  He commented how gross it was for men to hookup anonymously like that, and I just nodded.  I was looking for a relationship, I was trying to set up dates, and I was going to bring a nice man home to my family.
	I was in a dry spell for quite some time, and I was in desperate need of some water. I researched.  What is correct bathhouse etiquette?  What is the Watergarden?  An article called “Both Sides Now” by Richard Sine from 1996 he popped up describing how the Watergarden operates, and then I read this section:

Many men who meet at the Watergarden later become good friends or long-term lovers. John Gamber, the general manager, estimates that hundreds of men who met at the Watergarden have married since the bathhouse opened in 1977. A few of them have been wed at the facility itself. 

At a gay bathhouse?  I didn’t have my hopes up, but the stories like this of how people met, how they promoted safe sex, and just the idea of going to gay resort appealed to me.  I decided one morning morning that I’d go.  I was so nervous I arrived too early for their pool pass special and paid full price.  When I walked in it was nothing but light.  They turned on the lights to clean up the hallways and rooms.  California summer sun bright outside where the pool, a row of lawn chairs, and the hot tub were.  Wading in the hot tub was a warm way to end a productive visit.
	And there were many visits.  On my second visit, I met the man who became my boyfriend.  After meeting weekly for three months, he told me he loved me in a deluxe room of the Watergarden.  I didn’t respond right away and told him I had to think about.  The next week, I told him I loved him back, but with conditions.  
	There were days I went by myself. I learned when to say I was from San Jose, and when to say I’m not from San Jose. Or to say my name was the cold but loving Darcy or just not to say my name at all.  A man once introduced himself to me as Fred Flinstone.  Another the former chancellor of a prestigious college, and when I looked up his name he was telling the truth. Once, a group of us sat around watching Medea goes to Jail, and laughed when Medea went to jail and cheered when she was set free.  I sang Happy Birthday to many people.  
My boyfriend and I would continue to meet at the Watergarden as well.  It was our getaway from our separate crowded multigenerational Bay Area homes. The Watergarden was a place, at least for six hours, that was just our own space.  Where we could be together, eat some lunch at Sushi Infinity across the street, and go back to sleep because were content and full.  We would be with friends at some parties they threw.  On Christmas you’d see Christmas cards from former patrons on the wall. My boyfriend and I held each other as it turned to the New Year, 2020.  
	We hoped the Watergarden would be closed for a couple months, but it went out of business. At the end of an article about who bought the property one expert said, “The site has a bright future.”   But there was a bright past.  A piece of what some gay or bisexual men knew of San Jose, where, yes, to hookup, but those love connections did happen.  Especially when many men, including myself, fell in love with the space.

properties.statement: A brief glimpse at part of my San Jose.
properties.bio url: Resident of San Jose for more than three decades.
properties.text submission:
When one hears the refrain "Do you know the way to San Jose?" one might reasonably wonder which San Jose. Like most interesting places, San Jose is a blend of many components, some use the image of a salad, others use the image of a stew. No image or metaphor can adequately express the sources and changes that have molded San Jose. From the First Peoples who inhabited the area before the arrival of the Spanish through the growth of agriculture and the arrival of Portuguese and other communities of workers there was change. Change continued, technology grew in place of apricots and San Jose gained more people, many from Viet Nam and other parts of Asia. San Jose became the home to Low Riders and wonderful Pho and great technology. Key to this rich and vibrant San Jose is people, people who make San Jose their home.
    The Capitol Square Mall is one of the places where the people of San Jose shop. At one time it had an independent video store, a Montgomery Wards, a Lucky supermarket and a diner which advertised their fine traditional breakfasts. Now Capitol Square Mall reflects change. The video store is long gone, eclipsed by chain stores such as Hollywood Video which in turn gave way to streaming services. The diner is now TK Noodle  The Lucky Supermarket  is no longer there, now there is Cardenas Market where one can practice their Spanish while shopping the produce section. And there is a Starbucks next to the market. Actually there is a second Starbucks for those in the know. Some years back the Montgomery Wards was torn down and a Target was built; and in that Target store is another Starbucks to provide caffeine to those in San Jose at the intersection of McKee Road and Capitol Avenue.

properties.statement: Postcard designed by envisioning as a collaboration between mediums, people, water, and time. These handmade postcards are shown with sewn front designs based on traditional Japanese patterns in Sashiko, with handmade paper and a hand sewn stamp.

I am from the smell of the morning dew and Plumeria
From 豆浆 (dòu jiāng) and 油条 (yóu tiáo)
From Sichuan pepper, cumin, star anise, and tangerine peel
I am from Chinese food
I am from the taste of the spicy hot pot
Mushroom, tofu bubble, and pickled pepper
Sweet potato noodles and tomato scrambled eggs
Corn soup always reminds me of my childhood
I am from the sounds of Mandarin and Cantonese in Guangdong
Zǎo Shàng Hǎo (早上好) and Zou San (早晨) 
is the beginning of my day
The wind traveling through the streets
From the sound of gears spinning on a clock
I am from a planet in the universe named Earth
I am from Luohu District, Shenzhen, China, and Asia
I am from the hearts of my best friends
I am from inside of my dreams 
where the places I can achieve all the adventures
properties.bio url: Jiamao Yuan is a visual artist from Shenzhen, China.

properties.statement: On the morning after my ninth birthday, I carried a cerise suitcase and left Sadec, Vietnam on a mythical journey that eventually led to San Jose’s Little Saigon, a land where traditional foods were cooked with slightly different ingredients and where the people spoke with newly adjusted tongues. No matter where I went, I was slightly out-of-place. And so it became, that out of the necessity to invent a place to belong, poetry found me. My poetic instincts were formed from the sights and sounds of those immigrant streets and the vibrations of roads and buildings that were both familiar and foreign. It is the poetry of a body and heart learning its new language in secrecy.
properties.bio url: From the Mekong Delta to the Tenderloin, Lê immigrated to San Francisco at the age of nine.  Lê holds an MFA in Creative Writing from San José State University. Her publications include Corridors (2001) and Little Sister Left Behind (2007). Her poetry has appeared in numerous literary journals, including: Bayou Magazine, Borderlands: Texas Poetry Review, Hypertrophic Literary, The Minnesota Review and The Suburban Review. Lê is currently working on A False Dawn, a poetry collection about the Vietnamese-American immigrant experience.
properties.text submission:
Đi Về (Little Saigon)

Immigrant road, a far-reaching whip, 
and me, returning to my origin with new skin 
to parade through that crowded cul-de-sac 
of adopted mothers, cousins, aunties 
(chị cả, bác, cô, dì, thím, mợ), 
in-laws, exes, sisters and grannies, 
who are all related in the mythical 
entanglement of họ hàng, 
and whom I’ve spent decades weeding 
from my carefully cultivated plot.
Not rootless but wanderer just the same
through the bloodline of dragons 
and immortal gods, born of the same womb
to the same familial bondage that binds 
as blindly as faith; how do I carry on 
when distant traditions keep me in my place?

properties.statement: This was very fun

Basis of Sex is about the fragility of our democracy and the great power we’ve granted our court system to endow or take away our civil rights. The fragility of women’s rights are front of mind with the passing of Ruth Bader Ginsberg and the impending appointment of Amy Coney Barrett. I chose a stereotypical feminine pastel pink palette to represent the uncertainty of a woman’s role in the world that will be defined by a Conservative court. I wanted the space to be beautiful at first but disquieting upon closer inspection. Symbols of our institutional strength are cracking or on rocky, uncertain ground. The rocky column on a fragile glass pedestal is placed to the right of center to represent the court moving to the right. On the far left wall, a 28 light installation represents birth control and a woman’s autonomy over her own body.  

I also wanted to evoke our climate emergency and the potentially catastrophic power the court has to alter climate policy. The orb represents our Mother Earth, overpopulated, and morphed into a toxic planet. For the scale of the orb, I was inspired by Andres Reiseinger proposal for a gallery show in which he uses a giant orb to create an uncomfortable experience for the viewer. I wanted to similarly create discomfort with the inescapable scale of this impregnated wall. There is a gallery bench placed uncomfortably close to the orb to represent the overwhelming scale and discomfort of the climate crisis.
properties.location: 200 E Santa Clara St, San Jose, CA 95113

properties.all hashtags: History of Marginalized Communities in San Jose
properties.hashtag: History of Marginalized Communities in San Jose
properties.statement:
Parthenia M. Hicks
Artist’s Statement
San Jose Storyboard Project
May 2021


As a writer and poet, I believe it is my “job” to observe and describe what I see. “Peacock” describes a marginalized San Jose community by telling one story of prejudice culminating in carefully crafted and planned physical and emotional violence toward gay people at a particular time period within San Jose’s history. 

“Peacock” describes incidents that occurred in San Jose at the former Valley Fair Mall before it was demolished and replaced with the current mega-mall, Westfield. The story is told on behalf of the many voiceless gay men and women who lived in the area during the days when gay people were rounded up and hauled off to jail—the period just before and after the Stonewall Riots in Greenwich Village began to shift the oppressive view of gay-ness as criminal behavior. 

As the manager of what was then the largest bookshop in the South Bay, a two-level much-loved shop that served San Jose for many years, I personally, along with the bookshop staff witnessed the persecution of gay men who were “set up” by cops pretending to be gay in the men’s bathroom just outside the downstairs bookshop entry. These men, often young boys, ran through the bookshop crying out for help and were frequently slammed into the mezzanine floor, stepped on, handcuffed, arrested and dragged out of the shop to face criminal charges.
properties.location: Valley Fair Shopping Center now known as Westfield Mall, near the Macy's entrance on Steven's Creek Blvd.
properties.bio url: Parthenia M. Hicks, M. Div in Kriya Yoga, Los Gatos Poet Laureate Emerita, is the recipient of the Silicon Valley Arts Fellowship for Literature; the Robinson Jeffers Tor House Poetry Prize; the Villa Montalvo Biennial Poetry Prize, the Dragonfly Press Award, and Pushcart nominations for poetry and fiction. Her most recent publications include “Cold Mountain Review” and “Red Wheelbarrow.” A resident of San Jose since 1972,  she currently shares her space with her Burmese and Egyptian wild cats, Shiloh Rose and Citrine Moonbeam, who assist Parthenia as she works on her forthcoming manuscripts, One Night She Swallowed the Moon and Praying in the Women’s Bathroom.
properties.text submission:
Peacock

Just ask any legitimate bookseller. To that person, the job isn’t “retail,” it’s a choice to stay up close and personal with physical books. Physical books—the kind we sit with, open, sometimes feel unbearable pain when the spine is broken. Those people. They work in City Lights; Shakespeare and Company; Powell’s; The Strand—inside walls that contain more than forays into the highlights of literary genre. Yes, joy visits in the shape of famous and not-so-famous writers who sign books, stay for coffee or wine with the staff. These secret moments when we feel connected to the vessel that brings the words that move us, shake us up, soothe us, tear us apart, remind us of something we’d rather forget or urge us forward. Sure, those are the perks, but they’re nothing compared to the incandescent moments that happen behind the scenes, exploding quietly, away from sales, displays, bestsellers, “great” literature. The stories that surprise, imprint on the brain, make a lasting groove. The Shirley Jackson or Octavia E. Butler moments. 
The flat sound of a register reading a title. The punch of the price. The crinkling paper bag that swallows its prey. The flat thud of a body hitting the mezzanine floor of the bookshop. The skinny, threadlike sound arising from the silken throat of a young gay man, trapped, held down, terrified. The sound that lifts like a sparrow in flight, that hits the ceiling, floats, lands inside each customer who waits in line to purchase a prized volume. A bird fluttering, butting up against the heart wall, trapped, fighting with all its might to escape. We know this moment.
The cashier makes small talk with customers while the young man, in the glory of his alluring worked-out musculature, his protein shakes and club-danced body writhes in fear. In this moment, the boy is a peacock, a lavish and tender bird, an emerald translucent messenger, calling out in flight, reaching, but catching only air in his feathered grasp, trapped. His predator, cloaked in the uniform of justice, wears a badge. Police, dressed in tight t-shirts and bulging jeans hide in the Valley Fair men’s bathroom, “setting up” gay men. Officers who speak the briny lie that tortures, drags down the queens with such satisfaction. Slam a boy’s head on the landing, step on his pride, but never confess to that one hot kiss and the thrill of handcuffing his prey.
Saturday night the young man dances wildly, flashing his youth, his precious stamina, his holiness at the Crystal, the Savoy, Renegades, the Toyon. All around him sexy love blazes, but the one guilty of being himself cannot remember this in his holding cell where incessant terror spits at him, hollows him out like termites in wood. 
The cashier takes a break. Sits quietly in the backroom taking small bites of something. It’s the night shift even when it isn’t. The woman’s panties left on the bottom shelf in Fiction; the dead bird smashed inside the picture book of birds; the man who purchases the new book on the Pleiades that he believes to be the source of the voices that follow him home each night; the vision of Lois floating down the steps inquiring about a job, lost blue soul about to die on the freeway. 
One morning the bulldozer arrives, ready to bite into the bookshop. Take the lid off. It’s okay. We’ve already celebrated the dire and the profound, downstairs below ground level where the great wall of books were received, where we went to tell our stories. The tunnel behind the backroom area will be filled in with giant rocks. There will be air pockets, space to hold the words we’ll leave behind. We use spray paint, magic markers, pencils, hammers to mark our sentiments, to say our holy goodbyes. Something is leaving us, but will still have room to breathe underneath the upscale mall that will rise like a bloated white whale over the same spot where Toni Morrison, Margaret Atwood, Michael Ondaatje have lived, their voices fire rushing through trees. We write poems to Lois, to all the beautiful young men who were captured—so great was their aura—and to the broken, diseased and lost who called upon us. To the joyous who projected their love onto us. To the woman who called at 6 a.m. asking us to save her kittens. To all those who assumed we could we rise to any occasion. Powerless though we were.

By Caitlin Pambid, Art 174, Fall 2021, SJSU

Kim Yasuda’s site-specific work honors Dr. Ernesto Galarza, a scholar, activist, community organizer and civic leader. The table is made of cast bronze and the objects on the table, such as a hat, book, and farm tools were created with inlaid bronze.

The large library table is the “centerpiece” of the work, and references Dr. Ernesto Galarza’s interests in academics and labor organizing.,The importance of family to Galarza is represented by the banquet size of the library table and the arrangement of the photos and texts. The single chair at the head of the table is bronze with a wooden seat facing west towards Cesar Chavez Plaza representing his balance as a field worker and scholar. Lesser known than the table and chair: there are paved Ribbons of Terrazzo, which have bronze texts in Spanish and English with personal notes about Dr. Galarza from family, friends, and colleagues. 

“Man on Fire” captures the influence of place and the individual on each other. Dr. Galarza’s work was framed in the geography of the San Joaquin Valley and the division between white and Mexican farm workers. His work also transformed the place from one of division to cooperation that laid the groundwork for the introduction of Mexican history to the schools. “Man on Fire” resists the separation of place and the individual to show the symbiotic relationship at work and his role in the formation of both.

properties.text submission:
How to Steal an Avocado
(first published in Snail Mail Review, Issue 1, 2010)

Notice: someone has left
an avocado delivery truck 
parked just here on a San Jose street.

If no one is looking, kick off your stilettos, 
clamber up, sit cross-legged 
among the cardboard crates mounding with fruit.

From the corkscrew in your purse, fashion a blade
to breach the leathery skin, a tender little violence
for quick reward.

And there in the truck’s deep cool mouth, realize – 
you are not unlike these alligator pears
which could not ripen on the vine.

How lucky that once plucked free, they found you 
walking on a palm-lined avenue,
hungry.

properties.statement: When the COVID19 pandemic began to spread across the United States, I turned to the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease’s Flickr account. I knew from previous experience that this would be where the United State’s federal research labs would share the first electron microscope images of the virus. In those early weeks, I was rewarded with colorized photos of our bodies at war and 3D structural models of a new enemy. As an artist, I searched every image for the turmoil of this moment— for what Wassily Kandinsky called the ‘klang’— and was left wanting. So, as I held onto the scientific scenes of an invisible war, I began to delve into the metaphysical crisis of a shared isolation. Alone in my basement, I created an abstract photographic series in which I imagined the microscopic landscapes of the human body as emotional and energized compositions. Using glass microscope slides and acrylic ink, I created boldly colored image plates and photographed them on a high resolution scanner. The resulting photos are expressive and abstract, while also hinting at the microscopic drama playing out within our bodies.

properties.statement:
Designed by artist, Rigo 23, this larger-than lifesize fiberglass and mosaic monument, centrally placed on San José State University’s Tower Lawn, depicts the heroic and symbolic action of two African-American athletes and San José State University alumni, Tommie Smith and John Carlos, who during the medal ceremony for the 200-meter running final in the Olympic Stadium in Mexico City on October 16, 1968, performed the Black power salute, raising their fists in silent protest.

Smith, in the first place spot and Carlos, in third, planned and executed the gesture to draw attention to injustice and inequality faced by Black Americans but were greeted with boos and threats from the audience. Rendering the iconic moment through details such as the gloved hands and shoeless feet of the two athletes, Rigo 23 shows that the gesture was not accidental but planned for maximal symbolic effect.

Reenacted at SJSU in monumental form, Smith and Carlos’s protest and call towards justice is uplifted and celebrated. The second place podium spot, left empty, invites spectators to imagine themselves alongside the two icons and to follow their example in pledging to take responsibility and action towards eradicating anti-Black racism and bias.

properties.statement:
from: Irene
to: You

I am from my breath
Breathe in, breathe out
With every inhale the memory comes closer
With every exhale it recedes a little

Breathe in, 
the vanilla of the toritos blooming
the musty heavy air of the rainy season
the honeysuckle outside my window
my baby’s sweaty skin when I come to nurse him 
Write them all down before you exhale, before you

breathe out and they are all gone.

I am from my mouth, 
that entrance into my body that has allowed 
nutrients in, laughter out 
What tastes remain in my mouth’s memory? 
What memory make my mouth water or my lips pucker?

I am from the taste of gallo pinto, 
acacia honey, cas and cacao
I am from 
bitter swallowed words
Sweet laughter
Spicy passion
Salty tears and sweat


I am from my ears
Ears that often hear too much and 
often don’t hear enough
Selective hearing 
Do they hear or do they listen?
I wish to listen
I wish to listen and understand
The chirping of the cicadas of my childhood, 
the rhythm of the waves, 
ancestral stories specially told by my grandmother, Tetei.


I am from, what some might call, a banana republic
from a small house close to the railroad tracks
from a singer sewing machine, 
a book shelf made of cinder blocks and planks of 
splintery wood, 
a vinyl tablecloth 
But mostly 
I am from the universe inside me where the history, 
the secrets, pain, happiness and dreams reside.
properties.bio url:
Irene Carvajal is a multidisciplinary Costa Rican-American artist, her art practice includes printmaking, collage, sculpture, video, performance and installation. Thematically her work touches on the intersectionality of colonialism, labor, feminism, value, mass production and environmentalism. She is an experimental, conceptual artist interested in materiality and meaning making through process and medium. Her research has lead her to explore sustainable alternatives to traditional methods and materials.

Irene has exhibited in the United States, Japan and Costa Rica. She received her BFA from the University of Kansas and her MFA at SFAI where she received the Bronze Roller Award. She is the recipient of multiple awards and grants for the arts and arts education. She has taught at several universities including Stanford, SFAI (where she served as chair of the printmaking department) and SJSU. She has participated in art residencies in Japan, USA, Mexico and Costa Rica. Most recently at La Ceiba Gráfica in Vera Cruz, Mexico.

Currently, she lectures at San Jose State University.

properties.text submission:
When we first drove into San Jose in 1963, the air stank.  The newspaper said something was off with the flushing action of the South Bay. The image seemed appropriate. 
	I had new wife and a new job SJS not (yet U) but almost no money, but we needed rest and showers. There was enough for one night in a hotel and we ended up at Hotel Montgomery then at the center of town. (Later it was moved 187 feet and is now Four Points by Sheraton San Jose Downtown). All night long, the same noisy cars circled round and rounded round. Next day we had to find a place to rent or we would have to dig into our month-in-advance rent money.  Incredibly, we found a cottage on a rich man’s estate in the hills above Alum Rock Park. From the lawn by the front yard swimming pool we could see a host of plum trees sweeping almost all the way to the Bay. The rent was 95 dollars a month.
	On a bright shiny November morning, I walked out of my English Lit class in the Journalism Building to the news that President Kennedy had been shot.  It wasn’t clear whether it was fatal. There were desperate hopes that it wasn’t, but, alas..., and the lamentations of a nation which could not believe or comprehend the fate it had been asked to live through began.
	My wife and I had no television set but our landlord invited us to look at the news with him and his family and for hours, over several days, we sprawled in chairs in his bedroom where the big set was, watching with tear-filled eyes a country trying to cope. 
	On the second or third day of grieving,  I heard familiar music, and looked up at the set. My graduate school, Rutgers, had a fine University Chorus that sang a concert a year with the Philadelphia Orchestra.  My last semester, it was Brahms German Requiem. There was Ormandy, the orchestra, and my old choir. They had been gathered quickly for a memorial service. I sang along as best as I could with my quavery voice.

I am from a song that no one else can hear,
an echo of a memory
that has long since frayed
where there are no more strands left to grasp,
except for the cold metal in my palm
チャリン  チャリン

I am from the taste of lukewarm coffee left unfinished,
bitter yet sweet, new yet familiar,
much like every farewell
where something raw and heavy rises in my throat
and I swallow it back down into the recesses of my chest
チャリン  チャリン

I am from the sound of the ever turning pages of a notebook
where it fills up as two timelines pass me by,
in the sepia-colored distance my grandfather sits at a desk,
counting his coins at the table
as if depositing them into an unseen box
チャリン  チャリン

I am from the water
where my ancestors' dreams collided
and my unwritten story began,
the offerings from my grandfather
ringing in my ears

properties.statement:
I’m from the smell of frozen laundry and long-expected summer storm,
And strong yet subtle lilac fragrance and oily scent of train platform,
The smell of mama’s tart sharlotka1 and stable’s pungent earthy tone.
I’m from nasturtium’s sharp aroma and stifling fumes of acetone.

I’m from the taste of tea with lemon and freshly fallen fluffy snow,
And sweet frost-bitten rowanberry that last I ate so long ago.
I’m from the taste of fried potatoes and sea buckthorn delicious mors2,
And sugar snap pea from the garden and dark rye bread both soft and coarse.

I’m from the sound of roaring thunder and gentle hum of bass guitar,
And from the power of orchestra and train that’s rumbling from afar.
I’m from my papa’s vibrant sneezes, from snow that crunches under boot,
And from the cuckoo’s measured chuckle and tragic ballad of a lute.

I’m from the ancient Ural Mountains from biggest country in the world.
I’m from the books I’ve read, and stories that I was once, in secret, told.
I’m from the quiet podvorotni3, from places filled with buzz and din.
I’m from the past, I’m from the future, I am from all that’s ever been.

________________________
1.	Шарлотка (Rus /sharlotka) – apple pie
2.	Морс (Rus /mors)– a simple drink made by mixing jam and water
3.	Подворотни (Rus /podvorotni)– archways in walls of multistory residential buildings, providing car access to inner court

I’m a lifelong writer and poet who has also worked professionally as high school
teacher, print journalist, network television story editor, and museum curator. My
unwavering conviction about the importance of our human connection to each other
and to the environment we share with all life on Earth, is central to my poetry and
writing.

When I first arrived in Silicon Valley thirty-eight years ago, I wanted to explore its
less urban as well as its burgeoning urban spaces. On weekends we often broke
free to travel backroads and byways that still resonated with vestiges of the earlier
residents, wildlife, vegetation and waterways that defined them. These day-trips
reinforced a robust sense of the relationship of people to the land they live, work,
and die upon.

Visits to national parks and designated open spaces across the U.S., and national
parks in other countries, inspire with their ongoing presence and accessibility the
preservation of open spaces, despite threats to reduce their acreage for commerce.
In the same spirit, Santa Clara County and multiple adjacent county parks attract
visitors to picnic, hike, fish, and enjoy nature. They also provide local opportunities
for respite and remembering.

Some occupations of previously rural spaces are now noticeably in transition, and
might eventually give way to urban expansion. Maybe this is all the more reason to
impart an awareness of past ways of being here into future memory—a charm
against forgetting not only what has gone before, but protection today against
over-development of living, breathing land.

San Jose is a cutting edge theater of technology for which we can be justly proud.
I’m happily here to also celebrate some of its less obvious “under-stories” as part of
an ongoing, land-based history of place we call home.
properties.title of work: Backroads and Byways of San Jose

It also put my own mid-life crises into perspective, and gave me a worthy focus at a difficult time. I keep wanting to write a light little novel or story series that brings joy to the world without bringing anguish to me. So far, that has evaded me because all my frothy little pieces turn into much deeper work when I expand them.
But this little mystery series--perhaps I could call it “flash mysteries”?--may finally accomplish that lighter purpose. I love San Jose and the tremendous variety of cool people who make it the hidden treasure it is. That’s why I gave my protagonist a multi-ethnic identity using surnames one can easily find in San Jose. I’ve long wanted to set a mystery series here, looking at our quirks and foibles (in a mostly loving way) and our gifts and talents while promoting laughter and hope. I also teach creative writing at De Anza and CreatorSchoolCA.com and private workshops where I've met so many creative San Joseans (Is that the name for San Jose residents?)

Her creative nonfiction “Pivot,” and short story, "Gardener's Delight" (Dragonfly Press DNA) were nominated for Pushcart Prizes.  She is co-founder of San Jose’s literary reading series, Flash Fiction Forum and will teach a class for in-progress novelists and memoirists for CreatorSchoolCA.com this June called “The Messy Middle.”
properties.text submission:
Excerpt from the first installment in a San Jose Mystery Series: Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Tiny Crimes by Lita Kurth
       Lydia Rotini’s cell phone buzzed, and although her lunch break was not quite over, the thought of human suffering made her swallow the last bite of banh mi sandwich, clear her throat, and answer, “Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Tiny Crimes throughout the greater San Jose area.”
      The woman on the other end could scarcely speak through her sobs. “A terrible crime has been committed in Willow Glen. Please I need your help.”
      Lydia was unsurprised. Willow Glen was a seething cauldron of small crime. Soothingly, she asked for the address, and after doublechecking that her best camera and crime scene tools were packed into her colorful Laurel Birch bag, she headed out to an address on Camino Palomino. When she reached the enormous fenced chateau, a big cardboard box stood in front of its locked iron gate, and she had to reach over it to ring the bell.
      Soon enough, a stylish older woman hurried down the walkway worry written all over her face in capital letters. “Are you Lydia?”
      “I am, madam,” Lydia said in comforting tones.
      “This morning I opened my gate to something I hope I never see again. I still can’t believe it happened. Someone dumped a bucket of dead leaves right in front of my gate!”
      Lydia’s brow furrowed. “Oh dear. I’m very sorry to hear that.”
      “I preserved the evidence,” the woman said and lifted the cardboard box.
 Immediately Lydia could see why the woman had said it was a bucket of dead leaves because this leaves were wet and held the shape of a bucket very clearly. Lydia regarded her gravely. “You’ve shown tremendous presence of mind. Sometimes in the midst of trauma, people unthinkingly destroy evidence.”
      The woman's blue eyes brimmed with tears. “Can you believe the police wouldn’t come for this?”
      “I can believe it, madam,” Lydia said, “but I cannot condone it. I shall endeavor to get to the bottom of this as well as the middle and the top. “
She surveyed the crime scene, “After I’ve done my initial physical investigation, I shall need to ask you some questions.”
      “Just ring the bell when you’ve finished, and I’ll let you into the house.” The woman dabbed the tears from her cheeks with a linen handkerchief. “And thank you.”
      Quietly pleased to be of service to the suffering, Lydia bent down with her tape measure and measured the top and bottom diameters of the dead leaf pile as well as its height. She photographed it from every angle and put on latex gloves to take a sample. Since it was November, they were particularly beautiful leaves which Lydia recognized as Chinese pistache. She picked up the leaf, sniffed it and recorded the odor: nutlike and autumny, with an earthy undertone. She crinkled one in her hand, then put it in a plastic ziplock bag.
When Lydia entered the chateau, the woman had laid out tea on a lovely trolley. Beside the teacups and exquisite Japanese teapot was a lace doily and on the doiley sat a bone china plate and on the plate sat several croissants that smelled exquisite.
      “How could someone do such a thing?” The woman asked in a heartbroken voice, adding “Cream and sugar?”
      “About a fourth cup of cream, thank you,” Lydia said. “No sugar.” She took a sip of tea. My but it was excellent. She looked toward the distant other side of the room and said somberly,       “I, a mere detective,  cannot pretend to plumb the depths of evil and madness that I encounter daily in San Jose. How could I? Philosophers and theologians have contemplated these questions for centuries and have not come to agreement. CONTACT LITA FOR THE CONCLUSION!

properties.statement:
The Interpreter is a prosthetic for translating one’s thoughts and feelings directly to a participator’s five senses. The prosthetic is highly intrusive which requires trust and a sense of safety. The room size, the slight fog, the warm colors, and closeup shots serve to counteract the intrusive aspect of the prosthetic and provide a non threatening experience. 

The Interpreter arose from the frustrations I, and many artists, have in verbally explaining our thoughts, feelings, and visions. The prosthetic is also a result of social anxiety. Being able to express myself as I am is much easier in smaller and more intimate relations.

properties.statement:
Written by Daniel Katra, Art 174, Fall 2021: The title of this work is an homage to the brightly-colored genre of Mexican folk art, originating from fever-induced dreams of Mexican artist Pedro Linares, in the early 20th-century, a central feature of the imagery contained in the mural. Franco works with a deep sense of responsibility to his traditional Mexican artistic roots, while focusing on giving back to the community through his mural work.

The restaurant, Mezcal, where the mural calls home, is named after a traditional spirit of southern Mexico, based on the fermented and aged sap of the maguey cactus. Many sacred aspects of indigenous culture are represented in this mural, connecting the building itself to a rich history which originated in Mexico, but is still alive and well, taking on new form and significance in San José today. Representing the mystical qualities of the mezcal is a 15-foot tall Nuestra Señora Immaculada de Juquila, patron goddess of the maguey plant.

The deity is depicted growing out of a bowl of black clay pottery which has its own place in the spiritual lore of the Oaxacan region. The famous black mole, which is the signature dish at the restaurant, is represented in the mural as well, visually representing in a way a secret code, one that is shared by the Zapotec people, embedded in their collective DNA, that is made manifest through their artistic and culinary traditions. This rich imagery speaks the story of the various indigineous groups from these regions in southern Mexico that live in San José, along with the owners and workers of the restaurant Mezcal.

properties.statement:
Produced by California-based Japanese artist, Harumo Sato, as part of the 2018 San Jose Walls mural program, this colorful abstract, painted on the side of 35-year old Dac Phuc Vietnamese restaurant, is a testament to the fact that public art doesn’t have to focus on difficult histories or moments of trauma to be a site of protest and action. Playful, joyful, energetic, colorful, Sato’s work uses pattern, mythology and biomorphic forms to explore the artist’s vision for a more healthy and peaceful world, one that embraces the fact that chaos and challenges are meaningful and unescapable.

These goals are mirrored in the larger San Jose Walls program, which brings contemporary artists to San Jose yearly in a live festival of art, music and community engagement. Working with and among the community, artists create work in their unique personal styles and their chosen subject matter. The resulting murals not only enhance and brighten the experience of locals and visitors as they make their way around the city, but serve as sites of resistance to narratives of urban decay. Instead, created as accessible and highly visible art spaces, these murals invite all to consider the thriving and diverse communities that make up San Jose.

“Celebration Under the Water” recognizes the story of Vietnamese Americans in the Bay Area in depicting the moves beyond the narrative of the Vietnam War to show that there is more below the surface. Vibrant colors illustrate the pleasure of life that occurs beneath the turbulence of the waves above. While the focus of the historical narrative may be on the conflict and trauma from half a world away there is a broader more complex story of life, joy, chaotic order, and community. The mural challenges the viewer to resist focusing on the strife of the rough seas to see the community that can flourish when diverse peoples come together in an ecosystem of respect forming a symbiotic society.

As a novelist, poet, and flash fiction writer (and teacher), I've long wanted to do a spoof mystery series, and this year, during Covid, I started one, prompted partly by the many, many, many walks I took through San Jose neighborhoods
properties.title of work: Excerpt from  a San Jose Mystery Series: Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Small Crimes
properties.text submission:
Lydia Rotini’s cell phone buzzed, and although her lunch break was not quite over, the thought of human suffering made her swallow the last bite of banh mi sandwich, clear her throat, and answer, “Lydia Rotini Hernandez-Nguyen, Specialist in Small Crimes throughout the San Jose area.”
The woman on the other end could scarcely speak through her sobs. “A terrible crime has been committed in Willow Glen. Please I need your help.”
Lydia was unsurprised. Willow Glen was a seething cauldron of small crime. Soothingly, she asked for the address, and after doublechecking that her best camera and crime scene tools were packed into her colorful Laurel Birch bag, she headed out to an address on Camino Palomino. When she reached the enormous fenced chateau, a big cardboard box stood in front of its locked iron gate, and she had to reach over it to ring the bell.
Soon enough, a stylish older woman hurried down the walkway worry written all over her face in capital letters. “Are you Lydia?”
“I am, madam,” Lydia said in comforting tones.
“This morning I opened my gate to something I hope I never see again. I still can’t believe it happened. Someone dumped a bucket of dead leaves right in front of my gate!”
Lydia’s brow furrowed. “Oh dear. I’m very sorry to hear that.”
“I preserved the evidence,” the woman said and lifted the cardboard box.
 Immediately Lydia could see why the woman had said it was a bucket of dead leaves because this leaves were wet and held the shape of a bucket very clearly. Lydia regarded her gravely. “You’ve shown tremendous presence of mind. Sometimes in the midst of trauma, people unthinkingly destroy evidence.”
The woman's blue eyes brimmed with tears. “Can you believe the police wouldn’t come for this?”
“I can believe it, madam,” Lydia said, “but I cannot condone it. I shall endeavor to get to the bottom of this as well as the middle and the top. “
She surveyed the crime scene, “After I’ve done my initial physical investigation, I shall need to ask you some questions.”
“Just ring the bell when you’ve finished, and I’ll let you into the house.” The woman dabbed the tears from her cheeks with a linen handkerchief. “And thank you.”
Quietly pleased to be of service to the suffering, Lydia bent down with her tape measure and measured the top and bottom diameters of the dead leaf pile as well as its height. She photographed it from every angle and put on latex gloves to take a sample. Since it was November, they were particularly beautiful leaves which Lydia recognized as Chinese pistache. She picked up the leaf, sniffed it and recorded the odor: nutlike and autumny, with an earthy undertone. She crinkled one in her hand, then put it in a plastic ziplock bag.
When Lydia entered the chateau, the woman had laid out tea on a lovely trolley. Beside the teacups and exquisite Japanese teapot was a lace doily and on the doiley sat a bone china plate and on the plate sat several croissants that smelled exquisite.
“How could someone do such a thing?” The woman asked in a heartbroken voice, adding “Cream and sugar?”
“About a fourth cup of cream, thank you,” Lydia said. “No sugar.” She took a sip of tea. My but it was excellent. She looked toward the distant other side of the room and said somberly, “I, a mere detective,  cannot pretend to plumb the depths of evil and madness that I encounter daily in San Jose. How could I? Philosophers and theologians have contemplated these questions for centuries and have not come to agreement.

properties.statement:
This is a suit that projects the innermost feelings of the person wearing this suit. It projects the wearer’s chains, the thoughts that the person can not let go. It can be trauma from their childhood or memories that they can never forget, whatever it may be, the TV will tell the story by projecting whatever has been displayed in the media from news channels to commercials to cartoons. T

he body is also bounded when wearing the suit to create the sense of restriction, the feeling of no escape which is comparable to one’s feelings when handling trauma and unforgettable memories.

Beams of Light beyond my screen is a visual letter to a shelter in place with a non-judgmental poetic gesture towards the unknown. There is a wonder being in the a new normal.  During such a time, one can build oneself up before seeing the city again, this time, a transformation of oneself.

properties.statement:
Created by Japanese American modernist sculptor Ruth Asawa, this memorial, located outside of the Federal Building, commemorates the forced removal and incarceration of Japanese and Japanese-American residents of California during WWII.

Sculpted in bas-relief bronze, the memorial depicts key aspects of the Japanese American experience, before and after the WWII with a central focus on the experience of the incarcerated Japanese Americans during the war. The mural includes scenes of immigration, community life and agricultural labor and alongside symbols of the incarceration camps, including barracks, barbed wire, a watch tower, and heavily armed soldiers.

The whole is accompanied by text panels that include Executive Order no. 9066 by which relocation to internment was ordained, maps of internment camps, and other historical documents. A native Californian, Asawa  herself, spent four years at an internment camp in Rohwer, Arkansas along with her family. 

While the memorial symbolically commemorates the experience of all Japanese Americans, it has a special poignancy in San Jose, whose thriving Japanese and Japanese- American community experienced forced removal, incarceration and loss of property as a result of Executive Order no. 9066. Moreover, On May 24 and 25, 1942, San Jose State University served as a registration site for local residents of Japanese descent prior to their forced removal and incarceration. 

The “Japanese Internment Memorial” pushes the view to resist the urge to assign the injustices of the past to the yellowed pages of history. Memorializing the relocation and removal of Japanese Americans during World War II serves as an inflection point for considering the treatment of different groups today – where there is a failure to extend dignity, equality, and justice.

The placement of the memorial at the Federal Building recalls the actions of the United States government to act without dignity, equality, and justice and serves as a permanent protest against the violation of civil and human rights.

properties.statement: One particularly cold night in December 2015, Stephen, a homeless man I knew slightly, died on the streets in San Jose. To the best of my knowledge, he was never identified, so his next of kin could never be notified. This was a tragic and somewhat unusual occurrence, but it serves to highlight the invisibility common to the homeless men, women, and children who live among us, yet who are set apart by a wall of fear and shame. They are pushed to the margins of society, but also to the margins of consciousness. Their near-invisibility allows the rest of us to forget their very existence—and when we forget they exist we don't feel any pressure to provide the resources they need to stay safe, healthy, and alive. This sonnet is a small memorial to a man who may not have received any other. He loved hot chocolate, cold beer, and mystery novels.
properties.location: 645 First St (under I-280), San Jose, CA 95113
properties.bio url: I am a writer, editor, and musician living in Silicon Valley. My work has appeared in RHINO, Catamaran Literary Reader, Gone Lawn, Reed Magazine, and many other literary journals.
properties.text submission:
The flags did not fly at half mast when he died,
no touch-holes were lit, no eulogies penned.
Not a woman wailed when the first cold clods 
knocked at the coffin, only old dame winter came 
bustling under the bridge to spread a shroud 
of frost over the case, while the streets winked 
all their sooty night eyes, and the wind wound 
a wreath of fallen leaves and hamburger sleeves 
around two newly decommissioned soles. They 
found him full face down in the dirt, as if a negligent 
god had laid him out SIDS-style, but there is no god 
to blame, only a city of careless kin. Counting all our
sins of omission—the meals not served, the answers 
not sought, this lost check of a man never claimed.

properties.statement:
Useless Phrases is a social art project that attempts to ease the burden of the useless, hurtful, or abusive phrases that we carry with us through our lives. Using geocoding, anonymously collected “useless phrases” are placed back into their location of origin. Geocoding will allow viewers to see and interact with the phrases that have been placed back to their original location.
Oftentimes the words we carry with us are surprisingly more mundane than we might think. Useless Phrases welcomes any and all phrases that participants wish to let go of. While we hope this project brings more awareness to verbal and domestic abuse and the significance of its harmful effects on us as individuals, Useless Phrases is not limited to abusive language. Some of these useless phrases can be spoken by parents, partners, or ourselves and may seem minimal in comparison to others. However we can not compare our pain, and healing thrives in authenticity. So please send us your individual and honest useless phrase. While using geocoding won’t erase these phrases it will hopefully ease the burden of carrying them with us on a daily basis.

Katharine T, Jacobs and Ian G. Fabre have combined their strengths and weaknesses to create an engaging social art project that attempts to heal and inform. 
Jacobs and Fabre have come to find through their unique life experiences and individual trauma that they are inspired by a shared interest in helping others and a desire for personal growth which has led to the technological birth the concept and experience of Useless Phrases.
properties.bio url:
Katharine T. Jacobs is an interdisciplinary fine artist. She received her BFA in photography from Oregon College of Art and Craft in 2010 and is currently obtaining an MFA in photography from San Jose State University. Her background in craft has instilled a deep passion for historical practices, fine construction and conceptual art. While photography is a focus, Katharine’s work has never been limited to that particular medium. She often incorporates text, objects, stitching, and soft sculpture into her series and installations. 

Katharine in an award winning artist and a seasoned arts educator with a passion for accessibility in art and education. Her teaching and art practices have always intertwined as she pulls inspiration and insight from her students. As an intersectional feminist artist, she aims to find new ways that art and education can be more accessible, approachable and inclusive.
Soy fronteriza

properties.statement:
By Lindsley Britton, Art174, Fall 2021, SJSU

“Urban Room’s” structure consists of elevated “rooms” formed out of brightly colored vinyl-coated chain-link fences decorated with colored diamonds. The chain link structures sit on steel edifices, creating additional “rooms” below, shaded by the chain link latticework and black fabric canopies stretched between the sections. The result is an inviting open space adjacent to a stage used to host events and community gatherings.

The shaded area and event stage transform the park into a platform for block parties, community gatherings, and organized events in San José’s arty SoFA District. Between events, there are picnic tables situated in the shaded areas, providing an informal neighborhood gathering space. Viewed from the street, the large, elevated “rooms” provide a colorful addition to the narrow strip of a park, reminiscent of colorful playground equipment. 

Urban Rooms is a public art piece about land use and communal space adaptation in the cultural production site of downtown San José. By choosing chain link fence as a building material, the design team invites dialogue about community and spatial division. Fences are designed to separate and divide, but by lifting the fences overhead to provide shade, their function is renegotiated.

Studio Teddy Cruz and Foreman have received international accolades for innovative  flexible housing based on informal architecture. “Urban Rooms” encourages resistance of the individual in favor of a communal space. Transforming the elements that would segment people, land, and communities to features that bridge division to form community.

Decentering the concept of individual space results in an experience where the viewer becomes a participant in critique of land tenure and use. Mimicking Indigenous villages, the structures demonstrate the interdependence between the individual and community. How neither can be whole without the other.

This postcard transforms into a mask. For some people, a mask may have been the most annoying thing during this pandemic. However, it always stays closest to you and protects you. Family are the closest people to you but could be the most annoying ones. I designed this postcard thinking about my family in Japan. I have not seen my family for over two years. This postcard could go back to Japan for me, stay with them, and protect them but in the most annoying way. 
Yamaori (Mountain fold) and Taniori (Valley fold) lines are from Origami practice. When you repeat Yamaori and Taniori, you will make a bellow, which is suitable for a mask. The message on the Taniori area will be hidden after making folds. Therefore, you won't see the Japanese message. This is the representation of how my personality changes based on what language I am speaking and where I am. I tend to be shyer in Japanese especially when it comes to talking to my family. Japanese family usually never say "I miss you" or "I love you" to each other. Also, it is easy to say "thank you" via text when I am in the US, but it is hard to say in person when I go back to Japan.
This was fun
properties.bio url: Creating colorful happy art and spaces is was I do !

properties.statement: I grew up in Almaden Valley. My father still lives in the house I grew up in. These poems are rooted not only in San Jose but in my father's two explosive marriages. Mental illness. Homophobia. All those things I didn't initially have language for until I discovered the possibilities of what poetry could do. It was my meal ticket out of there.
properties.bio url: Timothy Liu is the author of twelve books of poems and Editor-in-Chief at Saturnalia Books.  A native of San Jose, he is a reader of occult esoterica and divides his time between Manhattan and Woodstock, NY.
properties.text submission:
Thoreau


My father and I have no place to go.
His wife will not let us in the house—
afraid of catching AIDS. She thinks
sleeping with men is more than a sin,
my father says, as we sit on the curb
in front of someone else’s house.
Sixty-four years have made my father
impotent. Silver roots, faded black
dye mottling his hair make him look
almost comical, as if his shame
belonged to me. Last night we read
Thoreau in a steak house down the road
and wept: If a man does not keep pace
with his companions, let him travel
to the music that he hears, however
measured or far away. The orchards
are gone, his village near Shanghai
bombed by the Japanese, the groves
I have known in Almaden—apricot,
walnut, peach and plum—hacked down.



	 
Canker


The wound would not heal for days. But that was nothing compared to my mother who ran her mouth all over my body.

What people will do to be remembered.

The nurses cutting roses from the cards I sent have put them in a tub of scalding water. The kisses have come undone.

Stamps are all she can save, arranging them in a book like all the photographs she could never take.

I have managed to piece together the pages she tore away from me. Though the box of letters burned, the ashes were not entirely extinguished.

The day after Christmas break, my father was driving me back to school, the two-lane highway on fire, everything falling. 

To me, their divorce was never final, only a precarious extension, a bridge I had learned to walk between two cliffs.

I remember blood on the dining-room floor and a few drops down his cheek when I broke a chair over his back. It wasn’t damaged beyond repair, but it was put away in the attic.

And I thought, if only Mother knew. The county had already locked her up for the first time that year: her neighbors had complained about sacks of garbage she threw from her balcony into the swimming pool below.

I still can hear her voice that day in junior high when I was called out of class. She said to me in the backseat,

Love me, let me die,

her head bobbing in my lap, floating in its pool of chemicals. The woman who couldn’t get in to clean drove us to the emergency room.

Let me die.

That’s all I heard when I broke into her bedroom, the pills scattered on the floor like a broken necklace.

She lived. That night there was a canker in the back of my throat. I couldn’t eat for days. My father opened cans of a protein drink he’d brought home from the hospital.

Drink this. Now sleep. Good.

That was the first time I remember being held. I told my father at the end of our trip. I told him about the men who came into my life. The pain that made me feel alive.

My father wept as we swerved to the side of the road. Then he began to speak, stoking a bed of ashes that years could not put out:

Your aunt wrote me while you had stayed with them, still a baby. You’d scream if your mother came into the room where you were being bathed. Her sister told her not to touch you but she did.

I wanted this to stop. Why couldn’t anyone stop her?

There are no photographs of you then. She wouldn’t have them in the house reminding her.

My mother entered me with a kiss.

At Easter break, I flew on a half-empty plane into the eye of night. I didn’t bring her flowers, though I thought of how they would look on a grave.

I wanted her in the earth, her body contained.

Not floating down a river of fire. Not knowing the words she said to me that night would burn:

Your father lies. Please God, don’t hurt your mother. You were always so difficult, crying, crying. I couldn’t shut you up. You didn’t want my milk. Only your father. How could I live with myself?

After we cried, I put out the light. I left her in that room. I closed the door behind me. 

Tonight my roses bloom beside her bed, working their thorns into her lips, the words I never knew how to say:

Mother, nothing heals completely as long as I stay alive.

properties.statement: The effects of sheltering in place has affected many people across the world. One of those effects is the smaller and closer social circles that are held onto during this time. Shot as a double exposure on film, this postcard image puts a silhouette of my roommate and a small body of water together into one piece which are metaphors for our own friends, family, and headspace. Even though it can be difficult to stay in contact with some of our loved ones, they always linger at the shorelines of our mind.
properties.location: Barack Obama Boulevard, san jose, ca

properties.statement: Around the world, people tell stories and legends of things that go bump in the dark. Something always unexplainable, unseeable, and unfindable. But what if these “monsters” are real, or rather, manifestations of inner human problems? Did they exist before us, or do they exist because of us? How come only few sightings exist, but not by the public eye?  With postcards I emulate what a wildlife researcher would see if everyone were to see these “inner monsters”. (Photos taken at Hellyer Park)
