properties.hashtag2: Visual Arts,We too are San José,Social Justice
properties.statement:
By Adrienne Defendi, Art 174, Fall 2021, SJSU

Created by renowned artist and muralist, El Mac, in collaboration with writer and artist, Chris Myers, the arts collective The Propeller Group, the urban contemporary arts gallery Empire 7 Studios, and The San José Museum of Art and the Children’s Discovery Museum, “Sophie Holding the World Together” brightens the San José urban Discovery Park and offers a striking symbol of hope and human presence that dominates the wide-open green park. The young girl, at a colossal scale, holds in her hands the world (a globe) and a lotus flower (symbol of humble beginnings). Her arms are raised high in ritual, strength, reverence, openness and acceptance. She looks just slightly down on us (her chin ever so slightly tucked in) the imperative urgency.

The mural hums with dynamic energy; and indeed the two portals, which lead to the Children Discovery Museum’s arcade where artists and musicians often perform, welcome the public and further encourage openness and fluidity, community and culture. The child in this mural, however, is neither mythological nor fantastical, but represents a brave and self-possessed seven year-old from Los Angeles named Sophie Cruz, an American activist who advocates to protect the undocumented and fights for United States immigration reform. Though she is an American citizen, her parents are undocumented (in contemporary terminology she is of a “mixed-status family”) and she lives, still today, in fear that ICE (Immigration and Customs Enforcement) will deport her parents back to Mexico, her family’s country of origin.

“Sophie Holding the World Together” challenges the viewer to decenter themselves and attempt to perceive the world through the eyes of a young woman. In stepping back and considering her perspective on what the world would be like if empathy were employed in immigration policies and practices. The representation of the hope of a new life and the potential to contribute to the betterment of the world is asking the viewer to resist taking the easy path in seeing immigration as an issue and not as a human experience that deserves understanding and compassion.

Around where we live, Grand Century Mall in Little Saigon is my son's favorite place to go. When I was younger that area was a Price Club wholesale store. Fast forward to now and there's so many fun places to eat, drink, & enjoy. We go there pretty often. My submission is a visual illustration of a typical day there with us. It's cool seeing what excites my 3 year old son. He loves the water fountains, the arcade, & the toys. We'll usually hang out at the little arcade for a while. Everything in there just gives me nostalgia. From the coin machines to dance dance revolution, it's pretty relaxing. The food court has our favorite foods, the stores are all unique, everyone there is super friendly & inviting.
properties.bio url: I'm an Artist/Designer. I've lived in San Jose all my life. From King & Ocala to Tully & Mclaughlin, San Jose has always been home. I grew up taking the bus & walking everywhere with my mom, exploring the diverse culture of our city. Today, I drive around town & do the same with my son. Creating & exploring along the way.

properties.statement: My poem depicts a particular San José intersection, near my home, that might be said to exemplify the severe inequality, homelessness, addiction, and mental suffering in our midst. I hope we will do more as individuals and members of our communities to make this good seed of a city into a more cooperative and purposeful place place to live.
properties.bio url: I'm an MFA student at San José State, with a Poetry concentration.  I've lived in Midtown for about a year and a half.
properties.text submission:
Park Ave. at Race St.

If you race to this corner and park your wheels
cool your engine and take the place in
at the intersection of homeless and gentrified:
uncollected trash scrapes manicured gardens
(who asked for pale grey sameness anyway?)
workaday scenesters can drink the atmosphere
of grit and struggle among full-time stragglers
and what can you ever really do? 
Let me ask myself while fishing 
for crumpled attempts at penance
when time though not the same as money
makes a better payment like attention
in this city of a million human souls
where even the beggars stare at their phones.

properties.statement: As a writer, I want to contribute to the healing of the human heart.  As a catholic woman, my heart is healed in my writings as I believe my pieces are the homilies I had to hold silent.  I was nervous in writing this piece as I have never experienced racism.  I am interested however in how xenophobia gets buried and disappeared in those of us second and third generation immigrant kids who are white and will never know the lived and bled struggles of our BIPOC neighbors and loved ones.  I believe it is my duty and I know it is my great joy to live and write with what poet Galway Kinnell calls, “a tenderness towards existence.”
properties.location: Five Wounds neighborhood, East San Jose, Cambrian neighborhood of San Jose, California
properties.bio url: Michelle S. Myers is a bilingual psychotherapist, originally from and currently living with her faithful terrier mix Perry Berry Benicio Myers in the Valley of the heart’s delight, San José, California.  Brought up a left-leaning catholic, Myers no longer is waiting for Rome to wake up to women’s ordination, but has decided to go ahead on her own, and ordain the women around her who are spiritual writers, teachers, leaders, activists, and mystics.  She was very influenced by the Jesuit principles of God in all things and social justice in her formative years which led her to travel, volunteer in, and live in Latin America for many years.  Myers finally learned Portuguese during her four years as a Maryknoller in São Paulo, Brazil.  After a time of working in community mental health and advocacy for immigrants, Michelle now works in private practice and is thrilled to occasionally commune with the writers of her Friday morning writing group led by professor, poet, and novelist, Lita Kurth.
properties.text submission:
I survived 2020 hanging out in my dear friend’s backyard under her Mulberry tree and solar-powered blinky lights, her husband serving us his excellent margaritas. She’s a sociology professor and I’m a shrink, thus we ramble, but profoundly so.  We discuss relationships, podcasts, and we also consider housing, work, feminism, and xenophobia in our San Jose.  San Jose was under our micro and macro analyses this year as we stayed home divided;  not hugging, not having birthday parties, not knowing what was coming next.  

Since I’m part Portuguese, my friend later sends me part of these macro studies — a multicolored map of San Jose from 1937.  She’s been introduced some to the Santa Clara Portuguese community with their interminable masses and train-laden gowned Portuguese princesses at her church.   The brightly colored apparently cheerful map is interpreted by Mapping Inequality— published with commentary from home loan officials who sliced and diced San Jose according to color, class, immigration, and ancestry.  “Hazerdous” communities in the San Jose of 1937 included African-Americans, Japanese immigrant communities, Mexican immigrants, and Portuguese immigrants.  “You should really look at these,” my friend says, referring to quadrant D-9 in red which describes its inhabitants as “an infiltration of low-class Portuguese, Mexicans, and negroes.” 

I suddenly imagine me, and the dignitaries; UFW co-founder Cesar Chavez, and our nation’s poet laureate, Amanda Gorman standing in that undesirable red quadrant (very east from where I grew up in the Cambrian neighborhood — now often referred to as Willow Glen by real estate agents) near 26th street and East Santa Clara.  I’m the only one of us three in my fantasy who could potentially hopscotch out of the undesirable red square within a generation.  Sal si puedes— “get out if you can” — only facilitated with my white skin.  White skin —doing nothing but being white —trumping even Gorman’s exquisite mastery of words brought to life with her free-bird hands and harmony of inflections, and even Chavez’s saintly courage and lifetime devotion to convincing the powers that be that people need to be treated as human beings.  In this English-speaking whiteness, I never knew I was part Portuguese until I was about 15.  I remember asking my grandpa about my grandma’s vinha de alhos dish, and he— hiding his Lithuanian Ashkenazi roots (even to his death)— laughed, “Hey, be sure you don’t marry a portagee!”  

My mother, an Irish-Dutch-American nurse of Montana copper mining roots, got our family  involved in our church’s devotion to Chavez and Huerta’s Si se puede movement.  The newborns of Central Valley farm workers were being deformed by big agriculture’s pesticides, and so my brothers and I never ate grapes in our childhood.  I still feel guilty if I eat them now.  I always knew the Irish were boisterous, and that the Italian side of me allowed for homemade raviolis at Christmastime.  But the Portuguese part remained a mystery to me, hidden in the inheritance of this “low-class” status that my grandma was determined to make invisible under her French glass, British flatware, and American patriotic pride.  My mother, following Chavez’s strike, brought to the heart of our kitchen table the inequities that she wanted to teach us were social sin— even down in our tastebuds.  Stratification gets cuttingly sharp close up.  

Like most Portuguese in San Jose, I’m Azorean.  My grandma was raised by her grandma, Ana Mattos who hailed from lush Faial, one of the rural farming and fishing communities in this string of nine islands.  It’s about three hours flying out into the blue Atlantic abyss from Lisbon.  Although now a hipster vacation destination, the Azores are their own kind of “definitely declining” D-9 red-lined community east adjacent to mainland Europe’s prestige.  Outside of the quadrants of racism, they are stunning island paradises full of resilient Azoreans.  My grandma, born in 1916 did not gift me with her ability to speak Portuguese, nor approve of my parent’s Catholic Church which stood in solidarity with Mexicans — she was all too aware of the dangers of revealing those dividing lines emphasized on that 1937 map decoded by my sociology professor friend and Mapping Inequality. My grandma, Eva Alberta Mattos Landucci made sure to erase all those beautiful “low-class” vowels in her name, shook that red line from her body, and shielded by her white skin, buried any traces of color that would deteriorate her children’s and grandchildren’s cultural capital.

properties.statement:
I AM FROM: Lucia Znamirowski

I am from the smell of breath. Language, speech, pain raved in me from the galactic presence that protects us. What is spoken, pronounced, tends to be consumed. 

I am from the taste of East Poland. I felt thankful after meals, so I couldn’t believe in god. If not for the aversion to the smell of wine or blood, I could think I was a good woman.

I am from the sound of reading ancient authors. Feeding cats in the street.  For this is the only way to forget having to know myself.

I am from a memory.  Not to know. A landscape raw with curses, building upon what came before. Evidence, the light unyielding.
properties.bio url: Lucia Znamirowski (born 1985) is an American interdisciplinary artist. Znamirowski is an MFA Candidate at San Jose State University in San Jose, California.  A former artist in resident at Kala Art Institute (2010) currently working as a project manager on San Jose Story Maps Project with artist, Rhonda Holberton.  Znamirowski is moved by ideas of memory, time, and change. She is known for her installations of DIY materials, drawings of women and animals, often executed with strong black and white contrasts.  Always building upon what came before, she continually re-visits her compositions, re-creating them in an attempt to copy them, while understanding the impossibility of this pursuit. She chases these ever changing differences between each art work as proof of our constantly shifting existence.

properties.statement: "Metcalf Rd." is about a hidden untold story that harkens back to "old California" before San Jose became the heart of Silicon Valley and even before the Valley of Hearts Delight.  Natural beauty awaits those patient enough to find it, even in San Jose.
properties.bio url: I have in San Jose since 1976, an ardent local environmentalist, poet and essayist.  I have discovered hidden gems in San Jose's natural landscape.   Enjoy this one.  Craige Edgerton
properties.text submission:
METCALF ROAD

There are hidden treasures to be found in San Jose if one looks.  For me, the untrodden natural areas teeming with native flora and fauna, recalling “old California”, are the crown jewels.  Places that have been lightly touched by modern “progress”, the path less taken, are the diamonds in the rough that I seek out.

Metcalf Road is such a place.  It starts at Monterey Road and serpentines eastward up Metcalf Canyon, steadily steepening to the top.  It is a jewel for those few willing to explore its secrets.  I am one of those few, possibly the only one.  
 
Metcalf Road is my relief zone where I can escape Spring pollen and muddy trails in the winter rains and still get a good workout up the roughly 1,000’ climb. 

The magic of Metcalf Road is that her riches are not apparent at first.  She doesn’t want to reveal her secrets until she has tested you to see if you are worthy of her hidden gems.  So, for years, I hiked it with my head down, pushing as hard as I could to get the exercise I needed.  No time to explore, to look at the hidden nuggets she had to offer.  I couldn’t waste time looking for hidden secrets!

And all the while that I was head-down hiking, pushing myself to the limit, Metcalf Road was slowly working her magic on me.  

At some point, I started keeping a tally in my head of the different birds I saw such as Lazuli bunting, yellow warbler, Ash throated flycatcher, Western kingbird, says phoebe, California thrasher, Anna’s hummingbird, Northern harrier and Golden eagle to name a few.   And I became aware of some of the plants that were beginning to flower.  Each season brought a different palette; Spring saw poppies, blue and white Lupin, goldfield and the stunningly beautiful Blazing Star; Summer brought Bushmallow and elderberry; Fall produced golden Sycamores and bright red toyon berries.

This may sound like a paradise but there are also thorns in that rosy picture.  Metcalf Road is also a dumping ground.  Because of its remoteness, folks drive up and dump their trash into the canyon.  Old cars, mattresses, kids’ toys, refrigerators, tires and general trash lines the steep canyon almost all the way to the top.  There was even a dead body found in the bottom of the canyon about 20 years ago and there are currently 3 markers for people who recently died there. 

For some, this would be just the excuse to never come here.  Why would anyone want to hike up a narrow, steep, dangerous windy road with trash scattered along the side?  The answer is that most wouldn’t.  But for those willing to look past the detritus of our modern civilization, they can find the beauty of old California, a hint of the pristine habitat that was here before we tried to completely muck it up.  And it’s in plain sight.  

Metcalf Road is not a unique place in the world and will never become a World Heritage Site.  It is just a common road that leads from here to there.  But, like so many places that still exist, one must slow down and look for the beauty.  It is easy to be in awe of Yosemite Valley but to find that inspiration in a little relatively unknown road that is hardly on a map, that is a true find.  

The point, my friends, is that beauty and awe-inspiring nature are everywhere.  Just take a few minutes to slow down and look around.  Take a few minutes to sit quietly in your backyard and see the stories that are playing out every minute.  Look up in the sky, as when you were a young child, and see how many characters appear, morph and then disappear in the clouds.  Go out on a clear moonless night and try to count all the stars that you can see.  Stop and look closely at an interesting plant.  

Metcalf Road is a non- descript, seldom used, little known road that winds its way out of San Jose.  But, because I was able to slow down and accept her riches, in spite of her attempt to hide them in the trash and lost lives, I have not only discovered a little-known gem but have found a new friend who has offered me her friendship and opened her arms to me.   I accept and treasure my new friend.  May we remain together for many years.
									Craige Edgerton
									December 2021

properties.statement: I often write in short forms—prose poems, flash fiction, lyric essay—forms usually less than 750 words. Specific concrete image is central  to my work. I try to be aware of the sensory world around me, and I keep a small journal for note-taking wherever I go to record compelling observations, things that catch my attention. Also, I have a particular affinity for modes of travel, for airplanes, cars, and especially trains, the no-place places of liminal time and space that enlarge my imagination. I wrote “Missed Train” as a haibun, a traditional Japanese form that pairs prose with haiku via an associative leap. The prose poem portion recalls a typical street scene near San Jose State University where I taught for over ten years—typical until the pandemic closed the campus. The haiku reinforms the memory with an image and observation  from the perspective of our new abnormal and repurposes a quote from a well-known modernist poem, another era of significant societal shock and dislocation. While “Missed Train” looks back at the before-times, the disjunctive nature of the haiku’s post-pandemic lens on a lost world, as well as the double meaning in the poem’s title, frames this San Jose story a Covid Chronicle.

properties.bio url: Sally Ashton, MFA, is a poet, writer, teacher, and editor-in-chief of DMQ Review, an online journal featuring poetry and art. She is the author of four books. The most recent, The Behaviour of Clocks (WordFarm 2019), is a poetic inquiry into time framed by Einstein’s thought experiments. Honors include fellowships from Arts Council Silicon Valley and the Lucas Artists Program at Montalvo Arts Center, and she served as the Santa Clara County Poet Laureate, 2011-2013. She has taught at SJSU, UC Santa Cruz extension, and at local and international workshops and was Visiting Poet for Fall 2020 semester in the SJSU MFA program. More info can be found at sallyashton.com
properties.text submission:
Missed Train


After class, the paseo swarms with students and their appointments with tea, coffee, all sorts of smoke. They cluster around small tables set out in front of three competing cafés that line the promenade. Farther down, a garbage can lies overturned, trash scattered. Maybe the aluminum can guy was searching again. A man speeds by on his motorized wheelchair, the aged Chihuahua crouched between his feet yapping and lunging at each passing skateboard. Another fellow shakes a paper coffee cup at a driver’s window stopped at the crosswalk where I hurry past, headed to the light rail stop dragging my wheeled backpack full of papers to grade. It grumbles against the fake cobble pressed into the pavement. Across the street, an itinerant preacher in his twenties stands on a low wall. He grasps the neck of his red electric guitar strung over a shoulder, the other hand holding an open book aloft, loudly rehearsing a sermon to no one visible. People wait for a bus near the platform where I too will have to wait for the next train. The one I just missed clangs down the street, wheels whining around the corner. Just far enough back from the smoke-free zone to be legal, people light up. When a bus pulls to the curb, the doors let off some kid wearing a black beanie studded with multi-colored buttons. He produces a ukulele from his backpack as if that’s why he came here, as if that’s what we are all waiting for. He leans against a light pole and strums a calliope-like melody for everyone, the preacher, a child now crying in its stroller, her tired mother, the departing bus’ roar, and far down the tracks, its headlight just appearing, the next train.



Words left on paper.
The apparitions linger—
faces in a crowd
